Sentencas: Protonic ceramic fuel cells (PCFC) have emerged as a promising candidate for distributed power generation.
Titulo: Steady-State and Dynamic Modeling of Intermediate-Temperature Protonic Ceramic Fuel Cells

Sentencas: The reduced temperature cells (similar to 500 degrees C) have the potential to enable faster start-up times, longer life, and lower cost materials compared to oxygen-ion conducting fuel cells.
Titulo: Steady-State and Dynamic Modeling of Intermediate-Temperature Protonic Ceramic Fuel Cells

Sentencas: However, the modeling of PCFCs is confounded by several challenges, including estimating open circuit conditions formixed charged conductors.
Titulo: Steady-State and Dynamic Modeling of Intermediate-Temperature Protonic Ceramic Fuel Cells

Sentencas: Here we present the development of a PCFC computational framework for a predictive cell-level, interface charge transfer model capturing mixed conduction, as well as transients.
Titulo: Steady-State and Dynamic Modeling of Intermediate-Temperature Protonic Ceramic Fuel Cells

Sentencas: Our approach employs a 1-D heterogeneous channel-level modeling strategy that resolves fuel depletion and flow configuration effects along the length of the channel and is coupled to a semi-empirical electrochemical model.
Titulo: Steady-State and Dynamic Modeling of Intermediate-Temperature Protonic Ceramic Fuel Cells

Sentencas: The model is formulated in such away that allows for easy integration of modeling parameters extracted from button cell experiments and performance scale-up to cell-level predictions.
Titulo: Steady-State and Dynamic Modeling of Intermediate-Temperature Protonic Ceramic Fuel Cells

Sentencas: Humidified methane-fueled simulations display power densities above 0.125 W-cm(-2) at 500 degrees C, 0.15 A cm(-2), and 80% fuel utilization cell conditions.
Titulo: Steady-State and Dynamic Modeling of Intermediate-Temperature Protonic Ceramic Fuel Cells

Sentencas: Dynamic simulations indicate that the lower power density PCFCs (relative to solid oxide fuel cells) result in relatively slow thermal transients that could potentially dampen harmful effects of current-based fuel control during load-following operation.
Titulo: Steady-State and Dynamic Modeling of Intermediate-Temperature Protonic Ceramic Fuel Cells
